comments.commentBody: Bar / Restaurant in Philadelphia, PA: The Blockley Pourhouse (on or near the site of a genuine poor house / almshouse - see http://theblockley.com/aboutx.php)

#75,
Paul, obviously you have never visited Duke. There is not one preppy soul on the entire campus! Go Butler!
Always better to dump a player a year before he goes downhill than a year after.

EliottB (Harvard MA), #10 wrote "To quote the immortal and mortal Yogi Berra:
"It ain't over 'til it's over."
And as of the top of the 8th, Red Sox 8, Yankees 7." Final score, Red Sox 9, Yankees 7. And that game's over.

Harvard PhD

The MLS seems to be off to a nice start this season. By the way, is their official site still http://web.mlsnet.com/index.jsp? It shows standings from last season and the scoreboard shows the Galaxy/SLC final from last fall.

NYT editor: Their Web address (mlsnet.com) is unchanged, but the site has been redesigned. AD
They are playing organized and with passion.  They are building up attacks through the midfield... the kid Tim Ream is a fantastic player.  Now-- if they would just sit Dane Richards...

Hayward is just beginning to come into his own. A raw hunk of basketball flavored granite for Mikey Angelo. This kid just found out that just maybe he is good. Not Great, Just good. Just starting to sink in. Ever see him angry? When he's diving on the floor after a loose ball, his face is not flaming with Duke-like histrionics or legendary melodramatics or painted pain, this boy is smiling. Smiling! He's having fun. Naiveté you might say, living in a dream or knocking time with the lord (I surely hope not).
When this man-child learns to get angry, when he finds out he's got boundaries that should not be crossed, that the men out there around him are mean, jealous, insecure, illiterate, unsophisticated; he won't smack them around (tho he could), he'll score on them, he'll be waiting to block their shots, he'll burn their earlobes and part their hair (if they have any) with blind passes.......and he'll be smiling and getting better.
Game theory, indeed! Dare I say, Roll over Larry and let Gordy take over.

McNabb is nearly a decade younger than Favre or Warner--
who's to say what he has left in the tank? Maybe a lot. He's a strong guy.
This could be like Y.A. Tittle going from the 49ers to the Giants--
What a great start to the season. Nothing like those big come from behind wins!
#11 ... not sure if you were trying to be witty (you weren't successful) or are just a bit pretentious (this is my vote), but the MA next to that Harvard in #10 means Massachusetts ...

Good stuff in here to be sure,but as a lifelong participant in what was once "the sport of kings" the question remains:"does anybody really care? ".The minions of the racing world have shot themselves in the their feet so many times,and the cancer of instant gratifications both on and off the internet coupled with marketing myopia have left the prognostications,entries and results off the sports pages for decades.Yet,elsewhere,Australia,Japan,France,the sport thrives.How so?Isn't it time to take a look ?
Great Food, Reasonable Prices, wonderful and historic ambiance.

This American Life did a very interesting story on this plant last week. They examined the myriad reasons why the model failed for the rest of GM beyond this one plant. You can hear it at http://www.thisamericanlife.org...

And it's a hit in Europe because....
a) It has a way fun manual transmission
b) multiple engine options including a diesel

It won't be a hit in the US because...
a) It's an automatic
b) It only has one engine option

I'd buy a six speed/diesel combo

The C pillar on this vehicle is just huge.  Maybe that's for design reasons, but I don't find it at all attractive.  It seems impossible that the driver could see any person or other vehicle positioned near either of the vehicle's rear corners.  To my mind, that's bad design.

@Tim Liao

Hyundai was the most profitable automaker in 2009; there is no need for govt. subsidies.

As for unions not being as strong - that wouldn't be farther from the truth as the auto unions in SKorea are militant (Hyundai experiences at least 1 strike every year).

As for Ford and Kia, I highly doubt that it was the govt. not allowing a multinational to take control since Renault Samsung Motors is a subsidiary of Renault S.A.; GM Daewoo is largely owned by GM (70.1%) w/ smaller ownership stakes held by Suzuki and SAIC; and SAIC had a 51% ownership stake in SsangYong Motor Company.

Sorry, but aside from your apparent disdain for SKorea, pretty much everything you posted is WRONG.

^ Uhh, sorry that would be China.

Funny how the Mercedes F800 copied the new Sonata's radical placement of the headlights.

And oh, the LG Prada phone debuted BEFORE the iPhone.
That Packard is magnificent; but I'm not so thrilled with the bright-green paintwork.  Something more like the Rolls-Royce Brewster Green or Goodwood Green might have looked better.

" In other words, the iPhone doesn’t know it’s multitasking."

Technically, the app is multi-threaded. Any iPhone can do this, and many do.

One to think about difference between multi-threading and multi-tasking is that the app developer chooses what to throw in the mix for a multi-threading and the customer (end-user) choose the mix for multi-tasking. Or as you say, "sorry, no Pandora yet."

Thats a beutiful car and i would love to own one, unfortianatly american cars have earned a reputation for not being reliable driveing down resale value .Its totaly un true becouse lincolns are just as reliable as lexus.But you lexus fans keep thinking that... and  maybe i will  be able to afford one of these beuties used.

first, the weight of car is somewhat heavier compared to Lexus 460.
second, fuel efficiency is lower than Lexus series.
two thing is fixed, I will buy EQUUS.

send Tim Liao to head quart of kia in south korea and show him the shape of kia`s heart.
and what? When 1997 IMF..rescue..bla bla bla, it is a nonsense.

anyway, peter schryer is the savior of kia,
long live the king of car-design kingdom,peter schryer
I will buy peter schryer`s

Had dinner here during France/Italy football match. Told the waiter 'the place will probably be empty tonight', he responded 'Oh no, we never get any Italians or French in here'. With that, I knew I was in trouble. The place is a tourist trap, perfect for Russians and Japanese who want over-priced food served by staff with white gloves.
This place really is a classic. Great Italian food, great service. Crowded and full of older men with younger women. People watching at its best. James Bond would eat here.

Kubu Bali has aged, and not gracefully. It is dated , from 20 years before, when it was new , cutting edge , and excellent. The staff, is still friendly, but unmotivated, as occupancy has fallen. It is in need of serious renovation . Should visit before making reservation.  Granted, Kubu Bali still has its charm.
